author: {'steamid': '76561198132418963', 'num_games_owned': 95, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 75, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1712049891}
review:
This isn't a "point and click game" ...its a "point and click ADVENTURE!"  
  
I was one of the "fortunates" who played this game on NES in the 1980's when it released. My sister and I worked our way through it side-by-side. We were just about 6 and 8 years old, on the couch sharing a Nintendo controller, with nothing but a child's sense of wonderment to guide us. This was not an easy game for us. But we loved it. It challenged us to discover, punished us when we failed, and forced us younglings to be more observant and creative in our attempts to solve each new "dead end." Its one of the handful of games her and I can still mention at any time and say to each other "Remember Shadowgate? Yeah, that game was one of the greats."  
  
Well, its not the 80's anymore. Its 2024. All of my memories of this game are from 30+ years ago. I haven't touched it since. So when I saw it on sale for $3.74 I thought to myself "buying at this price is the least I could do to give thanks to these devs for keeping alive such a Great Adventure once adored by a couple of kids."   
  
So I bought it and turned it on... if only to give a quick curious look at that memorable first door... before continuing my adventure elsewhere on what could be 2024's GOTY: Dragons Dogma 2. Well, I think that other adventure is going to have to wait a bit longer then expected. I've only just turned on Shadowgate, been in 3 separate areas/rooms, but the vibe the game is creating has me immediately wanting more. The music is fantastic. Fit for a fantasy. The recreated graphics remind me of art you'd find on Magic The Gathering playing cards. I don't want to play it right now, I need to. I just can't wait to see if my adult self is as clever as the dynamic duo of children who played this gem so many years ago. Oh, and I've forgotten almost everything. I guess I still am one of the "fortunate ones."

author: {'steamid': '76561198119440829', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 931, 'last_played': 1711117030}
review:
Played the original on Nintendo and Gameboy Color when I was no older than 10. I got stuck so many times. Really enjoyed this newer reimagining.

Only thing I wish for this specific version - I wish the "retro" graphics actually meant THE RETRO GRAPHICS and not just over pixelating the updated images.

Do NOT pick "Normal" if you want even a little challenge. I had to FORCE myself to die, just to see if I could. I jumped into lava (had to tell my char to do it 3 times before he would), that type of thing. "Classic" will let you have all the silly deaths the OG relentlessly gave (I hope, anyway)

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561199087716511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1710286529}
review:
If you like puzzle-based adventure games, this is a nice remake of a very difficult classic game that has a lot of "quality of life" improvements like fast and easy save/load and multiple difficulty levels. It's a relaxed, turn-based adventure, getting item X to use in place Y that opens up the next part of the castle.

The puzzles are mostly logical and fun, although there are a few places where you have to use random item on random thing where "another" random item seemed just as valid. Still, those are the minority. The settings are interesting and the graphics are nice. On the downside, the interface is a little clunky. The audio is a bit repetitive and the story - 4 hours in - isn't super coherent.

I only played the original briefly, but overall I am enjoying this quite a bit.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984754244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 173, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1707424965}
review:
As far as an oldskool dungeon crawler adventure RPG for mobile platforms could go back when it was released. For the PC however this game and it's gameplay mechanics feels like a step backwards in time.
This could be seen as a positive, and perhaps it somewhat is, because it feels like a 90's dungeon crawler.
You could also see it as a serious downside is my guess if you don't have played these kind of games back in the days. 
But even for the ones that played and loved things like Elvira, dungeon master and Eye of the Beholder, are going to feel like this is like the old classics  but not entirely. 
It all is amusing but it is the game that is missing the dots on the letter "i".
Would i recommend this game? I somewhat would.
I would probably rate this for what this game is and it's budget.
I say 6,5 out of 10 points because in it's core the game feels like an android or IOS mobile game.
And it was before the PC release, for what i remember.
They should have left it there is my idea, but i do love this for what it is. Even on PC.
Check it out before buying this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198249508316', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1071, 'last_played': 1705286160}
review:
If you were a fan of the original, or the NES version like I was, you will love this game. Awesome graphics, high replayability no microtransactions, no game breaking bugs. THIS is how you release a game!

 Although you may need a guide. Some of the puzzles can be challenging and without a clear way to figure them out. 

Can we PLEASE get this same sort of remake for Deja Vu and Uninvited?? And also the sequel for Deja Vu, and while your at it, a remake verion of Beyond Shadowgate as well. I mean don't get me twisted I intend to get the NES like version of Beyond Shadowgate these devs are currently making and are about to release. I just want to see it in this style as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009430650', 'num_games_owned': 1703, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1703506328}
review:
I've just finished the easiest difficulty and I still had to use the hint system.  Great fun game once you understand how it works and it's background. The original Shadowgate game which is notorious for killing the player instantly without warning and that is part of the charm. I strongly recommend the casual difficulty to start off in unless you've played/suffered through the original.

The different difficulties expand upon the puzzles, items and even rooms so what was easy to solve at the easiest difficulty but end up being a more complicated puzzle requiring more items and searching. Higher difficulties also have a timer mechanic where your torches will eventually burn out. This was again part of the original game and 'tough adventure' design. So you're definitely getting a very different experience that's worth replaying!

So again, good game for what it is, a re-imagining of the original Shadowgate. However, the timer mechanic and sudden deaths definitely can be annoying so this will appeal to a niche crowd who like this thing. For everyone else, I do recommend (again) that you play the easiest difficulty/casual first to enjoy the game and then play it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979693740', 'num_games_owned': 5710, 'num_reviews': 313, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1696389042}
review:
Shadowgate either means something to you or it means absolutely nothing at all.  Though the original game was a MacVenture game - a point and click adventure series that had an odd window-based interface on the Mac's desktop - most people at the time didn't have a computer at home.  Computers at home, whether PC or Mac, were pretty rare and the Internet wasn't a thing.  The home console market crashed hard as well and it was Nintendo that single-handedly revived it with its NES and now-draconian "Seal of Quality" process to ensure that people were no longer tricked into buying unlicensed shovelware.  However, much of the market for the first two years were arcade ports or similar short-run quarter-munching style of games, especially action platformers that retrospectively coined the term "Nintendo Hard".  So a couple years into the NES' insanely popular run, Shadowgate dropped out of nowhere and provided an experience that nobody had seen before.  In a sea of run-n-guns, platformers, sword and sorcery action games, here was this unique-looking game split into several windows for menu, inventory, and wonderfully-detailed graphics that you wouldn't find in twitchier fare.  It didn't matter that it was insanely difficult and killed you repeatedly without warning, nor did it matter that the puzzles were obtuse and favored trial-and-error over logic; Shadowgate was unusually different than the rest of the market and for many people, its unique gameplay coupled with its haunting music was captivating, whether you were taking a chance on a blind buy or more likely you were renting it from your local video store.

It's difficult to express why this remake by Zojoi attracted a lot of attention because from any other perspective, the overall design of the game is archaic.  For veterans, part of the fun is simply how they subverted expectations, but ultimately the game is as obtuse as it has ever been.  Despite revisiting several of the puzzles and redoing them, changing sequences of events and outright overhauling certain areas, the game is still solidly anchored to trial-and-error and save scumming.  It's the only way you're going to complete the game without following someone else's guide, but some would argue that's also part of its charm.  By today's standards, most people would take a dump on this game precisely for the same reasons why people enjoy it.

Shadowgate is firmly rooted in the Us vs. Them era, when developers made it a point to harass and obstruct players from completing their game rather than gently guiding them on sight-seeing tours.  To finish Shadowgate on your own is an achievement of colossal proportions because a good portion of it is impossible to figure out without save scumming and risking countless deaths.  That's just what we did back in the day.  In fact, a lot of the time we couldn't even save because battery backups in a cart were expensive, so you just took extensive notes and tried again all the way from the beginning if need be because it really was Us vs. Them and we weren't about to lose!

I realize I'm reviewing this game almost a decade after it released, but I'm sure there's a good number of people who don't know it exists, but have fond memories of spending countless nights listening to familiar haunting jingles while the game actively sought to kill them.  For those folks, this version of Shadowgate is well and truly worthy of the name, if somewhat lacking the original's charm.  It's mainly why it took me so long to get to it.  Thrusting myself back into that mentality and hunkering down to take on the challenge was a daunting proposition that dissuaded me from actually doing it.

For everyone else, this game is an absolutely frustrating exercise.  Anyone expecting or looking for a casual, chill narrative adventure through an ancient castle can turn right around and walk out the door.  This game does not reward curiosity whatsoever.  More often than not, poking your head where it doesn't belong is a good way to lose it, perhaps even unfairly.  Unless explicitly telegraphed, there's no way to know if you're going to suddenly be met with a Game Over or why on earth you might want to carry 20 human skulls (protip: you don't.  A few is enough!).  All of the keys you find are unlabelled.  The spells you learn are just gibberish words with no way of knowing what they do until you find the place where they are actually used.  Remember that thing you saw in an early room that you couldn't get several hours ago?  You better.  Every action you take except for looking at things (an improvement over the original, actually), costs time measured in torches and if you're not using a guide at all, running out of torches poses a real risk.  I should also mention that you have to manually keep them lit because letting them go dark means you trip and break your neck.  I'm not kidding.

Shadowgate goes against all established adventure game procedure.  Do -not- pick everything up that's not bolted down.  Don't open every door.  Most certainly do not try everything you can and hope it works because Adventure Game Moon Logic.... sort of.  Like I said before, completing the game is heavily dependent on save scumming.  It's expected.  The game is 100% going to kill you for simply trying something out.  Repeatedly.  Save before doing something even remotely questionable.  Save before doing something entirely mundane.  Save multiple slots because guess what?  That banshee curse isn't going to cure itself and haha, you're definitely not going to cure it until much, much later, if at all.  Maybe you'll just die.  You probably will.

So for the modern point and click enthusiast, I can only say you'e got your work cut out for you if you want to dive into this nostalgic piece of work.  The art is serviceable if somewhat unrefined and lacks the pixel charm of the original.  The remixed music fades into the background and takes a less prominent role than it did on the NES.  The interface is even arguably worse than the original's on-screen action menu.  But this is a dyed-in-the-wool old school adventure game challenge with an old school adventure game mentality.  If you can wrap your head around it and understand where it comes from, the game becomes a much more palatable experience and is only forgivable in that context.  As a modern design, it arguably fails in every aspect, but since it is rooted in the original 80s release, it would have been disingenuous to  make it any other way.  That's what Shadowgate is and must be.

This version of Shadowgate is a rare revisiting of an older title that doesn't seek to change its fundamental identity.  It is purposely designed to be obtuse, illogical, and frustrating.  Yet it's also quite rewarding to the persistent player and while the narrative is standard fantasy fare, it all ties into a lore that the designer's been carrying around in his head for 30+ years and has been explored in sequels like Shadowgate64 and the upcoming do-over of Beyond Shadowgate (which leans heavily on the retro design, so look out for it).  But it's mostly about just giving him the finger because that's what he wants you to do.  He doesn't want to show you all the pretty pictures; he wants you to earn it.  You don't get rewarded for just following along and doing as you're told; you're only rewarded when you use the system against itself as you circumvent every death with a well-timed save, taking note of things and working your way through stuff the hard way, only to load when you've figured out the solution so you can save precious time.

The more Shadowgate hates you, the more you may come to love it.  The heart of the original beats in its chest and it's arguably lesser, but ultimately still the same experience with a new coat of paint. Just know that the water isn't warm and you're going to die. A lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038516866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1696788732}
review:
Shadowgate was one of my favorite games in NES-console way back when I was a young teen. The atmosphere was eerie, foreboding and the graphics were enjoyable, even though a bit rough-looking. This new version then... Why does it get a thumb down?

Well they changed the story and puzzles too much. It's not a same experience anymore. Spells have different names, some actions are missing, while others are heavily altered. Graphics are "okayish" - but not eerie in the same way than in the original. Fortunately some things CAN be changed to more classic setting. This is necessary especially with music. The New soundtrack is just unlistenable crap, and stetches way too far from the original, not being always even rocognizable. In a way, I appreciate what they tried to create here, but I really prefer the old 8-bit version over this any day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198216537667', 'num_games_owned': 1997, 'num_reviews': 305, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1693743593}
review:
Recommended with *huge* caveats.

I apparently got this game as part of a cheap bundle back in 2016- and to be honest, this is the only way I recommend getting this game. As part of a cheap bundle or at a seriously deep discount. (And yes, the fact that I got this as a CD Key somewhere means my review has no bearing on overall review score- so I am going with a Positive review rather than Negative.)

I never played the original game- never heard of it, as far as I can remember. 
It has Trading Cards- if you are a Completionist, you may just want to idle the game for the cards- the achievement unlock %s are rather low on this game, and to be honest, I don;t feel like that's because of difficulty- it's because you may have needed to play this game when it was a "cult favorite" back on NES to know what to do and where to go without having to blindly try to click your way through a few thousands clicks.

The map is huge- lots of rooms, lots of backtracking, lots of text boxes you have to click through over and over and over each time you revisit a room you've been in dozens of time already. No real fast travel- a few teleports that you will only use a few times- no fast travel using the map itself. My inventory seems to keep doing strange things and re-arranging things, which is frustrating (when I know the bar was in the third row, but it is now in the top row... huh.)
There are guides- use them, but expect some things to be inaccurate or different than what you see in your own game- mirror room, for example. The Apprentice Mode guide shows 6 mirrors in the room, while I only have 4 in the game. I haven't been following the guide step by step- only using it when I get lost on the huge map or am insure what Yorick's repeated hints actually mean. But I guess if you do things out of order, certain items don't appear, or they appear in different places, or the author may have gotten different difficulty modes mixed up.

The music is appropriate, but seriously repetitive and a tad annoying at times. The "This music means you are in danger, girl!" music when I am just sitting and looking around a room I have already looked around and cleared is a bit out of place for me.
The art is fairly typical for a Point & Click adventure from 10 years ago, similar to most HOGs/HOPAs too- don't expect intricate animations or photo-realistic graphics. 
Runs fine out of the box on Windows 10 22H2 on a decently beefy gaming desktop with an i9 11900K, 32 GB DDR4 RAM and a 3080 RTX ti. No hitching, no stutters, no tweaking needed. Also ran well on my older desktop with an i9-9900K, 16 GB DDR4 RAM and a 2070 RTX Super.  Could probably run on a toaster.

The save system is fine- make lots of saves in case you missed something or died- the gear icon in the upper right corner of the screen lets you save almost anywhere.

Don't expect high-action or any mind-bending battles- it's alright for playing short sessions and killing time- if you use a guide (if you never played the original game). Some of the puzzles are rather vague or obscure. And the achievements for *cure yourself in under 800 turns*- I am guessing that means clicks? Good luck with that if you don;t have the game and the map memorized already- you will be clicking a lot.

I will finish the game on Apprentice- but tbh, I am not likely to play it through again to try to unlock all achievements. It's too tedious for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010905516', 'num_games_owned': 836, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1692238080}
review: Shadowgate (2014) is a beautiful and engaging re-imagining of an adventure game classic. I enjoyed the NES version quite a lot although it kicked my teeth in and I was never able to finish it (as I refuse to use walkthroughs, regardless of how much it hurts my brain not to). I don't think this modern interpretation is as obtuse, so it's definitely a way in for those who weren't able to conquer the original games. The art is wonderful, the music is fantastic, the puzzles aren't too tough (at least on the "Normal" difficulty setting), and overall it's a short and very sweet adventuring experience. I'd definitely recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013206158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1700255356}
review:
I remember sitting on a swing as a little boy in the sun, inserting my first gameboy cardridge into the gameboy Color. Trying to see what it was showing on the screen due to the sun glare. There i sat for hours untill the batteries dieded and it gotten dark outside. The next day´s i would sit there enjoying the weather aswell as my gameboy that played the music from game Shadowgate on the background. Every now and then i would play a bit and just in case i got stuck again after hours of trying different things, I had a stack of printed papers of the playthrough right next to me. limiting myself to at least 2days of trying untill i give up and start using the playtrough guide that ´ve found somewhere on the internet with horrible telephone sounds.
Yes im that old by now. 

I bought this game when it came out on steam back in 2014 and still haven´t replayed it untill i found my old original gameboy and the shadowgate cardrige back.

Now that i finally did, ´ll finally restart start this game again. 

(its better than it already was, Thank you for this dev's i love this piece art).

author: {'steamid': '76561199035995434', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1672364422}
review:
*Playing this on my Steam Deck*

I remember playing this game all the time in high school! I love being able to play it on my Steam Deck (which it plays perfectly on after a slight control change). The story, music, art, and dialoge are nothing I've ever seen in a game! I could play this for hours on end. I have never really gotten very far in the game, so I'm very much looking forward to many more hours of it. :)

review: I grew up playing Shadowgate on the NES, and it was one of my favorite games of all time. This remake is beautiful, and really captures what my imagination saw when I played the OG version. It expands on the story with amazing narration and gorgeous visuals. This is a true gem, and an important remake of an important game in the industry. THIS is how you remake a classic!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971838196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 356, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1661562775}
review:
Spielwertung: 8.5/10
Spielzeit: ca. 6 Stunden
Spieldurchläufe: 1 (Ende)

Eines der schönsten Adventures, die ich je gespielt habe. Aber auch sehr schwer.

Normalerweise sind die meisten Spiele in ihrer Story und Präsentation bestensfalls Mittelmaß, aber Shadowgate hat mich völlig sprachlos gemacht. Die Einführung, die wunderbare Graphik, die Inszenierung, das ist Gänsehaut. Auch das Ende schließt eine passende Klammer. 

Dazwischen liegt ein völlig aufpoliertes Remake eines Klassikers aus den späten 1980ern (!!!). Irgendwie ist dieses Original auch in meiner Bibliothek gelandet, aber ich konnte mich einfach nicht überwinden es auch nur länger als 10 Minuten (!) zu spielen. Es ist einfach wirklich ZU alt, zu aus der Zeit gefallen. Damn, was für Sprünge wir gemacht haben. Es ist wirklich schön zu sehen, dass solche Klassiker so würdevoll manchmal ihren Weg zurück zu uns finden. Viele Menschen hätten vermutlich niemals Shadowgate ohne dieses Remake gespielt, ich zumindest zähle mich dazu. 

Ein Feature in der Neuauflage ist die F1 Taste, um die Graphik "auf alt" zu machen. Ob das wirklich die realistische Ursprungsgraphik der frühen 1990er Jahre auf Mac oder iOs war, keine Ahnung, aber es vermittelt einen tollen Eindruck.

Aber was ist mit dem Spiel selbst? Nun, ich denke, es ist schwer, aber nicht frustrierend schwer. Einen Großteil, ca. 70-80%, konnte ich selber rausbekommen. Der Rest teilt sich in die beiden Kategorien: D'oh auf, wo man das Gefühl hat, dass das Spiel in seiner Logik einfach dumm ist und unmöglich, wo man selbst nie draufgekommen wäre. Ohne die Hilfe von außen, Steam hat tolle Guides, wäre ich hier sicher niemals weitergekommen und hätte aufgegeben, aber die Zeiten, in denen man nach 30 Minuten frustrierender Suche einfach "am nächsten Tag mit frischen Augen wiederkommt" sind bei mir zumindest irgendwie vorbei. 

Dass das Spiel "nur" 6 Stunden Umfang hat, ist sicher ein zweischneidiges Schwert. Ich lasse das hier mal unkommentiert. 

Was ich sehr, sehr schade finde, und da bin ich sicher nicht allein, ist die Tatsache, dass die Entwickler im Abspann einen Nachfolger anteasern, der nur 2 Jahre nach Veröffentlichung, 2016 (!) herauskommen sollte. Nun, vielleicht hätte man sich lieber auf einen Trailer reduzieren sollen, aber in Wahrheit passiert ist: Nichts. Dieses Spiel werden wir wahrscheinlich niemals sehen. Vielleicht ja 2045 ;))

author: {'steamid': '76561198032128346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1407, 'last_played': 1653911738}
review:
Ich kenne das Original nicht, war also überrascht über die dunkle Atmosphäre und den Schwierigkeitsgrad.

Nachdem ich auf "klassisch / Geselle" meine Probleme hatte (Rätsel sind knifflig, Tode häufig und es gibt Unmengen Items mit denen man nichts anzufangen weiß) habe ich es im "Normal"-Modus probiert, der noch unter dem niedrigsten Schwierigkeitsgrad des klassischen Spieles liegt.

Da ist es dann fast zu einfach, weil man viel weniger Bausteine benötigt um das passende Item zu erhalten und überhaupt sehr wenig Items benötigt um Rätsel zu lösen.
Die Rätseldichte ist viel geringer und man stirbt deutlich weniger, weil das Spiel mehr Fehler verzeiht.

Das macht aber – vorallem wenn man weiß, wieviel Potential in den höheren Schwierigkeitsgraden steckt – auch deutlich weniger Spaß.
Denn dann ist „Shadwogate“ kaum herausfordernd und bietet kaum noch die Gene-typischen Kombinationsmöglichkeiten eines Point&Click-Games.
Man hebt die fertigen Gegenstände auf, öffnet damit etwas und setzt seinen Weg fort.

Ich werde nach diesem Low-Level-Durchgang das Spiel noch einmal auf einem höheren Schwierigkeitsgrad spielen, um mehr Spielerlebnis zu erfahren.

Was aber selbst in der gemäßigtesten Version des Spieles vorhanden ist, sind die hervorragenden handgezeichneten Cut-Scense im düsteren Fantasy-Comic-Stil.

Der Sound es Spieles ist atmosphärisch dicht, die Vertonung professionell, weshalb man das Geschehen auch ernst nimmt.

Ich finde die Grafik angemessen düster und für ein Fantasty-Point&Click passend.
Szenen und Räume sind abwechslungsreich gestaltet und – je nach Schwierigkeitsgrad – voller Items.
Auf Wunsch kann man diese mit F2 auch aufleuchten lassen.

Das ganze Spiel macht einen „Erwachsenen“ Eindruck und stammt ursprünglich aus einer Zeit, wo solche Spiele für Erwachsene oder Gamer, die sich „durchbeißen“ gemacht wurden.
Demzufolge sollte man sich darauf einstellen, dass man bei „Shadowgate“ oft scheitert, viel herumirrt und sterben kann.
„Shadowgate“ erfordert also eine hoch entwickelte Frustrationstoleranz.
Diese läßt sich aber an den Spielemodus anpassen. 

Ein Unding ist allerding, dass die Entwickler es immer noch nicht geschafft haben den Save-Bug zu beheben.
Viele Spieler, so auch ich, mussten feststellen, dass das Spiel gar nicht speichert, wenn man F5 (Quick-Save) drückt oder einen Speicher-Slot aktiviert. 
(Sehr frustrierend wenn man nach mehreren Spielstunden stirbt und dann feststellt, dass es überhaupt keinen Spielstand gibt, welchen man laden kann. Dies war auch der Grund warum ich den "Gesellen-Modus" abgebrochen habe, weil ich sowieso noch mal ganz von Vorne anfangen musste.)
Die Ursache für dieses „nicht Speichern“ ist, dass ein aktives Virenschutzprogramm, ein Speichern verhindert.
Man muss also – bei mir war es „Avast“ ausschalten / deaktivieren, um dann in „Shadowgate“ speichern zu können.
Sowas geht garnicht!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066103512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1652852690}

author: {'steamid': '76561198858771091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2233, 'last_played': 1650797609}
review:
This game is extremely expensive for what you get.  I like the atmosphere, but the controls for mouse are not well-designed.  It's slowwwwwww to react to your clicks.  You have to open the backpack and choose something then choose what to do with it and THEN close the backpack and then USE it on something.  Can't stand it.

Clicking through the text-boxes are slowwww.

Too much backtracking in the game.  Nobody likes to backtrack.  Just put in a function to open the map and click to where you want to go.  There's no random encounters going backwards, so just teleport the player there.

This game is overpriced because of its namesake.  It's a nostalgia hit piece.

There's a few interesting moments and the music/art style are very nice, but it's price tag should be $1.99

author: {'steamid': '76561198080493208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1635370563}
review:
This is more of a neutral rating, for clarification.

Old school adventure (Point and click) games can be really hit or miss for me. Oftentimes the intentionally impenetrable (and often illogical) puzzles along with that feeling of being "stuck" just drain the fun. Having said that, there are some great games in the genre, and sometimes they're really worth playing, and I find myself absorbed in their worlds. I was always curious about the Shadowgate remake that had been sitting in my backlog for a while, and I decided to check it out.

The presentation was really nice. The medieval setting with magic and mystery was portrayed wonderfully with the mostly static, but beautiful, backdrops. (There were some nice animations that sometimes played over the backdrops for added flavor.) You had the sense of being in this strange world of witches, dragons, castles and the like, and the soundtrack also added to that magical, fantasy flavor. In typical point and click style, there were plenty of puzzles requiring you to explore, find and utilize items in various ways to unlock progress. There were also magic spells that you picked up on your trek that could be tried out in different situations, and it wasn't always obvious if a particular spell would have the desired - or any - effect. Items could also be combined to make new items, another staple of the genre. As is the case with this style of game, figuring out what to do and executing is satisfying (or just imparting a sense of relief at times). You also have a talking skull as a side-kick that can offer hints if you wish, and there are multiple difficulty levels that change puzzles and items - very much in the vein of the Silent Hill series and I thought that was a nice touch, giving added longevity.

But, for some reason, I just didn't find myself really engaged - despite the positives. I'm not sure what it was. I was stuck for a while, and I realized at one point that I was struggling to find sufficient interest to even bother figuring out or looking up what was needed. It's not that the game was bad or poorly made - not at all. It's just one of those cases where this genre has to really suck me in in order for me to stay engaged. For the right player, I can see it being fantastic. I'm not a hardcore genre-fanatic and this one wasn't enough to rise above for me. 3/5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002637002', 'num_games_owned': 781, 'num_reviews': 357, 'playtime_forever': 2231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2231, 'last_played': 1637675913}
review:
Though it might look like a classic RPG, Shadowgate is a classic point & click adventure game. It's a remake/reimagining of the original MacVenture classic of the same name that imrproves upon the original with great, hand painted graphics, cutscenes, atmospheric music, and a classic fantasy story. 

Though I never completed, or got particularly far into, the original Shadowgate, I did play the game at one point when it was already a retro game. And for better or worse, this version still feels like the same game.

Overall it's definitely a game worth playing, with lots of good stuff about it! However, it's not a perfect game:
- Though mostly good, some of the voice acting feels a bit lacking. (Also, in a "hidden death", pronouncing the word wyvern as "woovern". xD )
- The game definitely has its own logic that you have to learn. Like how a lot of the parts of the game is "timed", though not in realtime, but through number of actions/steps; That different weapons practically has no actual combat use; How you must use the correct order when combining two items; Etc.
- There are so many red herrings and clutter items in the game that it gets a bit much.
- The music when your torch is about to go out is over the top dramatic, and it gets annoying after a while.
- The amount of commands are unnecessarily high, even with the "modern" option, and is another cause for confusion.

And although not something I consider a negative point, keep in mind that the game includes deaths, in a way very similar to classic Sierra games. In fact, there are many, many ways of dying in the game - enough to have four different achievements for it! The ten "hidden deaths" and a couple others are actually quite worth seeking out for some extra entertainment. But though I understand that it would've been a question about budget and costs, I do wish the normal deaths had a bit more to them than just a red screen and an entertaining text - and maybe a creature up in your face. But at least they went all out on the special deaths!

The achievements for the game are pretty good. Some are easy, others are are hard, but almost all requires you to actually get invested in the game. 100% in this game can probably done faster, but you're likely to spend about 20-25 hours on it. And despite several playthroughs, I didn't get bored.

I'll be buying the reimagined Beyond Shadowgate if/when Zojoi releases it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079426555', 'num_games_owned': 1024, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 702, 'last_played': 1627254913}
review: Good for nostalgia but gets old rather quickly. While a straight up remake wouldn't have been the best, the changes in puzzles and new items they made bring the game down a lot. The colors on everything are rather dark and some stuff is hard to navigate even with the glow button. There's a collection here on steam that has the NES version, get that one instead. Even after many years it's still better. Also after the credits they tease a game for 2016 that still isn't out yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101303964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2296, 'last_played': 1612684743}
review: I love Point & Click Games, but Shadowgate Remake stands out not just for giving a modern hot smoking graphical and gameplay rebirth to a legendary classic of it's time, but to bring with it it's strongest points and spreading out from it while preserving the core essentials. The adventure is simple you go inside Shadowgate, solve puzzles to progress (usually involving a lot of backtracking and items express), beat the bad guy, The End, the magic however is the in betweens of the adventure. You read very descriptive texts either through scrolls and books or by simply interacting with things adding to the lore and perspective of the world you interact with, you give a few chuckles and sometimes laugh to the multiple descriptive ways you can possibly die in the game, and probably the most curious of it is the adventuring itself! There are certain achievements there are tied to specific actions and sub-routes you take throught the castle, exploration is key and trial and error a must, it almost feels like a low-key sub-quest system as you play a streamlined adventure adding to the replayability, also it's worth mentioning that certain parts of the castle will be locked off depending on what difficulty you're on, if it's harder you'll unlock more, but you'll also probably not have enough time to explore everything as the game has a hidden timer mechanic based on how many torches you have available in your inventory to light on (there's another timer mechanic a bit early on which might frustrate you a little bit, but it does add to tension and reinforces the ''every turn counts'' mindset), so harder means more, but also less time, again the keyword here is replayability. There's a black humourous air to the game without losing it's seriousness, great for balancing it out without sounding too goofy, a personal thing to ''break the ice'' while maintaining the heroic-epic aspect of it, I hope they can maintain it for the upcoming Beyond the Shadowgate Remake, although I'll admit I have a soft-spot for the light hearted inclination it's classic counterpart had. In short, Shadowgate Remake is a great ressurrection of an already great classic Point & Click game, we need more of that these days.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015468878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1627053324}
review: Игра-приключение, где игрок перемещается с одного в основном статичного экрана на другой экран, взаимодействуя с окружением. Неплохая рисовка, некоторые локации. Вероятно игру обожают те, кто играл в оригинал, но я к их числу не отношусь. Оценивая же игрушку в наше время, сложно не заметить уйму недостатков, которые кстати исправить можно было без особого труда. Например, к игре прикручена карта, но быстрого перемещения нет - значит возвращаясь из конечных локаций в начало (а это придется делать не раз и не два), извольте пять минут бессмысленно прокликивать уже пройденные локации. В классических режимах игры быстро перегорают факелы и работает таймер, в казуальном - нет большей части интересного игрового контента, а пара встречающихся головоломок выглядит бессмысленно.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027874177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 687, 'last_played': 1625349927}
review:
Okay, I beat this game over several years and after a couple of restarts. I believe I beat it on the easiest setting, which means fewer puzzles, and the existing puzzles have fewer steps required to complete them. 
I am only decent at point and click games like this, and I understand that this game is designed to be on the harder side, but I still felt that some of the decisions the developers made only serve to add extra difficulty, while contributing very little to the overall enjoyment of playing. 
e.g. 
[spoiler]  There is a "room" where there is an angry wind elemental that the player must calm by playing a flute. the player cannot simply use the flute on the elemental as common sense would suggest, you must use the flute on yourself. the idea of using items on oneself is something that is very limited at least on the easy setting, and most items that the player applies to an external object are used by 'using' the given item on an object in a room. Now, I can understand having a strict "use the item on yourself" policy on the harder settings, but for the easier playthrough, this should absolutely function in a way where the player can either use the flute on themself or on the elemental.[/spoiler] 
of course this is just my opinion, but this moment in the game made me resigned to using a guide, and for me thats when i stop having fun with a game like this. 

It isnt a terrible game, the music, graphics, and overall theme are really cool, but unless you have a very high IQ and a taste for masochism I wouldnt suggest this game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068745755', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1620273300}
review: An incredible re-imagining of the classic Shadowgate. I grew up playing Shadowgate as a young kid. It was my first proper introduction to this style of game and is responsible for my continued interest in dark fantasy worlds. The gameplay is very similar to the original with some quality of life changes. The new puzzles add some challenge to the nostalgia trip without changing the feel of the game. Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991157647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 1128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 830, 'last_played': 1621389130}
review:
It's a good faithful remaster of the original NES version. There's normal game mode which is the very easy mode with puzzles still challenging enough for the casual gamer. Then there's classic with 3 difficulties, each difficulty (including normal) adjusts the puzzles, often times changing the solutions completely making each playthrough feel different in some ways. Master difficulty is the no lube mode for people looking for the true brain twister puzzles. 

I put it on master for my first playthrough, ended in me giving up on it. It's really damn hard but here's the thing, if you start off on normal and build your way up the difficulty ladder, you'll likely be in a situation where you understand enough, by that point, to actually tackle master. This gives the game surprising replayability where you'd least expect it from a game like this. If you find yourself struggling too much on the puzzles, consider playing on a lower difficulty. Remember to think outside the box, don't take things at face value. Put yourself in the shoes of the character and some puzzles will make sense. When you get yourself in the proper frame of mind you will find puzzle solving to be challenging but not frustrating.

One more time I'll emphasize, pick lower difficulty settings, even going as low as normal if you find the puzzles in the game are too frustrating for you. You'll be surprised that, after playing on normal and the skull friend helping you when you get stuck that your brain will become aware of the thought process necessary to figure out the puzzles in this game meaning you can move on to other difficulties with more challenging puzzles and perform better than you did before.

It's quite genius and I wish the devs would make a new shadowgate game because this is one of the best puzzle games ever made and this remaster is impressive work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129062591', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1670883282}

author: {'steamid': '76561199093357799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1610383223}
review: The 2014 remake of Shadowgate is absolutely spectacular (especially compared to the B&W Mac original); however, it's also quite a bit different. While the remake has many of the same elements as the original, there're far more changes and additions than similarities. The ahead-of-its-time graphical interface of the original has been reinvented and mostly improved for the modern approach to point-and-click adventure games, and while there're some minor aspects of inventory management and manipulation in the remake that are less than ideal, the overall gameplay is very enjoyable (especially since the challenge of having to keep a torch lit was eliminated). Therefore, despite the challenges I faced playing through the 2014 remake, I highly recommend it to anyone who loves Myst-style adventure games, especially adventure games with relatively few abstract puzzles. Having said that, be very careful which walkthrough you use (if you use one) because there're many different versions of this game. Even the best-fit walkthrough I could find still had quite a lot of extra elements, and I'm not exactly sure why. (But I suspect that the game designers kept tweaking the game after releasing it to make it more playable.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198119721446', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1607540533}
review:
Obligatorio para los que le tomaron cariño al original en NES o en cualquiera de sus versiones. Es difícil, y en comparación al original, tiene un buen replay value gracias a sus variaciones de dificultad y modos de juego. Esto permite sacarle un mayor provecho que de sólo jugar lo mismo una y otra vez.

Sirve de poco el conocimiento del original en esta entrega, y es todo un río de emociones volver a vivir la aventura con ese detalle de "es lo mismo, pero no es igual". A algunos les molestará, así que recomiendo verlo como una entrega diferente antes que como un remake 100% apegado al original. 

Gráficamente es bueno. No es algo impresionante, pero procura capturar la esencia del castillo cuidando de no pasarse de imaginativos. Es un estilo un poco tosco, pero que le queda perfecto para la ambientación de "historia narrada por medio de ilustraciones". En general, las capturas del juego son una buena perspectiva de qué se puede esperar al jugarlo.

La nueva música es más discreta que la de NES, y ello puede significar que te introduzcas más en el juego... o que sientas tu experiencia "empobrecida". Yo la he disfrutado mucho, y en cualquier caso, el juego brinda la posibilidad de utilizar el soundtrack original, así que por esa parte se respalda a sí mismo.
Las cinemáticas y efectos no son nada particularmente bueno, aunque el doblaje puede resonar en tu cabeza por varios días si entras lo suficiente en tu papel.

Los controles son una de las partes que más disfruté, y a la vez me molestó al principio. Si no te detienes a explorar las opciones, fácilmente puede sentir que no está bien optimizado para teclado y ratón. Navegar al menos una vez en las opciones para configurar el juego a tu gusto es fundamental; además de que ahí encontrarás algunos detalles que te permitirán personalizar tu experiencia de juego para tu particular disfrute.

Recomendado para los que busquen revivir de alguna manera esa experiencia que fue visitar este castillo por primera vez, resolver nuevos puzzles, y perderse nuevamente en sus habitaciones. Todos los amantes del point-n-click deberían probarlo al menos una vez. No recomendado para los que busquen el mismo juego de hace años pero con un cambio de imagen (dista mucho de ser eso), ni para los que quieran un juego que les ofrezca demasiadas horas de entretenimiento. Se disfruta más como la reinvención de un clásico, que como un videojuego moderno con múltiples mecánicas y lleno de contenido.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043471400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1607499106}
review:
I really enjoyed this game at first, then the absurd amount of backtracking ruined it for me. What makes it worse is that every time you enter a room, you have to click through the same pointless text boxes over and over, and you do a TON of backtracking midway through the game. It's even worse if you don't actually know where you're supposed to go, and you wander around for hours without realizing you have to backtrack through 80 empty rooms just to flick a switch, then go ALL THE WAY BACK through 80 other rooms to grab some obscure item, just to solve another puzzle that's ALL THE WAY BACK near the switch you just flicked.

The best word to describe this game is "tedious." I got it on sale for like $5 and I still wouldn't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961109000', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2845, 'last_played': 1614659378}

author: {'steamid': '76561198021442265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 223, 'playtime_forever': 1257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1257, 'last_played': 1592709295}
review:
I'll recommend this on sale and if you're nostalgic for the original games (I grew up with the NES version, personally). This is a remake, keeping some elements of the original, but expanding on and changing the rest. There are still a handful of obvious, idiotic or unexpected ways to die in nearly every room (and achievements to find them all). You will still get frustrated with some of the puzzles.

Upsides:
-Music and artwork are good. Nice to be able to play the original chiptune soundtrack as well.
-A bit more story is available this time around.

YMMV:
-The game is timed by the number of torches you have. Like the original, you'll likely restart a few times to complete parts you've memorized in fewer steps, giving you more breathing room for later.
-There's a new choice in difficulties that affects how many torches are in the game and how complicated the puzzles are. However, it also leaves some content out of the game on easier difficulties. You may be best served playing through on the easiest difficulty and working your way up. Starting out hard can be very frustrating without hints.
-There's a significant number of red herring items and rooms, especially in the easier difficulties. This is faithful to the original, but is just as annoying when trying to solve puzzles.

Downsides:
-There is a second timer mechanic added to the early-to-mid game, which can be very frustrating to deal with.
-A few of the "puzzles" (especially goblins) are just inconsistent trial and error. There's no logic. Just guessing and then reloading your game after your head gets bashed in yet again.

The game ends with a preview of a Shadowgate 64 remake, which never came to fruition apparently.

author: {'steamid': '76561198837143813', 'num_games_owned': 40, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1604614594}

author: {'steamid': '76561197983180562', 'num_games_owned': 105, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1221, 'last_played': 1574306524}
review:
Score: 7/10 - GOOD
This game is a remake of the old Shadowgate game that I played on my old 8-bit Nintendo when I was in elementary school.  It’s a point-and-click adventure game in a spooky castle, notorious for its dozens of ways to get yourself killed. The artwork and music are exceptionally well done and faithful to the original. Unfortunately, solving a few of the many puzzles seems to require tedious trial and error, and when I eventually stumbled upon the solution I found myself asking, "How on Earf was I supposed to figure that out (without trial-and-error)?!"

author: {'steamid': '76561198357862916', 'num_games_owned': 84, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1586939339}
review:
As a child, I grew up playing the NES version of Shadowgate and was very much looking forward to this remake. The fresh new take on the soundtrack, the visuals, and the additions to the story were very much welcomed. 

However, I would say the Shadowgate remake doesn't hold a torch to the earlier iterations. The pacing is less refined, the game features an overabundance of items and areas, that may or may not be related to or provide you with any insights to the solutions required to help you progress. And that damn Banshee curse...that was just cruel.

 I loved it 30 years ago and I still do, but this game is complex, I would avidse you to look at the  manual and read up a bit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093378763', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1594173876}
review:
Look, this is mostly getting a rec because I remember thoroughly enjoying the NES version of Shadowgate when I was younger. That said, though there are similarities, it is not the same game. Personally, it would have been nice if they included a second mode where you dropped all the cg cut scene updates and just used the new base graphics to play through a literal remake of the NES version.

or something.

Anyways, this one is entertaining but far less 'easy' than the other game i finished yesterday, that Mage Initiation Elements thingy. So if you want an adventure game challenge, this is one of the harder ones IMO.

Anyways, it is entertaining overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993023804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 524, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1584280169}
review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#453 out of 612)... it's time for Shadowgate.

Shadowgate is, I believe, a remake of a classic adventure game—one that I've already reviewed, I think, in the "MacVenture" series. The original, uh, hadn't aged very well. This remake is gorgeous and slavishly faithful to the idea of the original game if not the original game itself—it's a brutally difficult point-and-click adventure game with countless puzzles, many of which are new to the remake for any returning fans who somehow remember the original 30+ year-old game vividly enough to recognize the original puzzles. Visually the game is gorgeous, as each screen is lovingly hand-painted. Few games, in any genre, manage to nail their aesthetic quite so well.

And, you know, that's basically the only reason why I bought the game in the first place. What can I say? I'm a sucker for games with pretty art styles. Sometimes this lands me an unforgettable classic, like Okami, that I'll adore for the rest of my life. Sometimes it gets me something like Shadowgate instead.

Which is not to say Shadowgate is a bad game, just not for me. There's not much narrative here, just a lot of puzzles. The setting is really interesting and the art very evocative, so the experience as a whole is very compelling... I'm just not a fan of the constant slog of point-and-click puzzles. And the interface felt really confusing to me, too, to the point where I dreaded each click of the mouse. I dunno, maybe I'm being too harsh on the game. Shadowgate feels like a game I could really enjoy if I could just... come at it from another angle. It's one of those games I imagine I'll reinstall every couple of years to give another shot, and who knows? Maybe one day I won't bounce back.

If you're looking for a dark fantasy adventure game with a vividly Gothic aesthetic--bordering ever-so-slightly on the grotesque, and can muddle past the UI issues and don't mind (or even enjoy) the puzzles, I daresay Shadowgate might be the best game on Steam for you. And maybe one day I'll be in the right frame of mind for it to also be for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973044527', 'num_games_owned': 1024, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1586095718}
review:
This could have been a good game, but the interface was a huge letdown. Also there's a LOT of backtracking in this game, and it is SLOW! There's no fast travel, which makes it worse, And the interface makes backtracking even more worse on top of that. They could have easily put fast-travel in but I guess they were just lazy. The map could easily have had some fast-travel functionality. Maybe they wanted to keep the "old-school" feel of the original, but in this day and age when people are so time-poor, it's just inexcusable.

The puzzles were ok but not intuitive at all (par for the course in fantasy games really), and the instructions are in the form of riddles in scrolls and books. And reading them and trying to keep track of the information is a huge painful chore thanks to the terrible interface. You'll eventually throw your hands up in the air and consult a walkthrough. There are far too many useless items in the game which confuses matters even further.

After a while I just got sick of it all and just wanted to be done with the game so I used a walkthrough liberally during the latter stages of the game. If one has to consult a walkthrough, then it's not a good game.

The story isn't too bad. Music is decent. It's fairly short and simple game. However the overall experience was poor due to the terrible interface.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991465063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 241, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1438471866}
review:
This is a point and click adventure game

Tried this game and completed the first puzzle. I knew at that moment this game was on a whole new level. I can admit that i know this game is way to hard for me. 

I know i should have given it more time and really try. I usually do but i knew it was something of with this game. I thought to myself that i should look up the next puzzle so i can get a feel for the game. 

I looked and i was amazed for how hard the puzzle was. I looked at another and another, how could anyone figure this out?

I am no expert but i have played a few point and click games but this was just absurd. I may be unfair but i did not like the game and it's mainly because of the hard difficulty level.

4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198097421013', 'num_games_owned': 669, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 692, 'last_played': 1583092399}
review:
Point-and-click квест в сеттинге тёмного фентези. Мне захотелось взять игру, когда увидел в трейлере, как дракон поджаривает главного героя до хрустящей корочки (ну это же просто пушка).

Максимально [strike]пафосное[/strike] эпичное вступление расскажет про некую «живую» крепость Shadowgate, в которой творится некоторая атмта, а наш герой скачет в эту башню по наводке мага, чтобы навести там порядок и прочее эпическое бла-бла-бла.

Это вроде как ремейк квеста 1987 года (не играл). Игра поощряет смелость и сообразительность, только это будет пушить прохождение вперёд. Чистокровный квест, в котором доступно 9 классических действий: бить, взять, использовать, открыть, закрыть, идти, есть, говорить, смотреть. Все эти способности можно и нужно использовать на чём угодно и в контексте некоторых ситуаций эти эксперименты возымеют успех. В игре преимущественно придётся тщательно сканировать локации на предмет ценного лута, слоняться по всему замку в поисках куда этот ценный лут присобачить, уклоняться от стрел, прятаться за щитом от огня дракона, драться с гоблином, оборотнем, погибать от ловушек и всего другого понемногу, что для классических квестов не свойственно. В конце даже есть боссфайт (ну почти) на посохах. Забавно, когда я вышел к боссу и пытался стрелять из посоха, который до конца не собрал и мне показали [strike]пафосной[/strike] эпичный GAME OVER.

Игра принимает во внимание дефицит внимания у людей этого тысячелетия, поэтому по нажатию F2 все предметы, с которыми можно провзаимодействовать, подсветятся. Игру можно проскакать за 1,5-2 часа, но если вы такой же тупой и не сообразительный, как и я, то в игре придётся скрипеть мозгами 10+ часов.

Из особенностей: моего английского уровня «My name is Diсk» для комфортного прохождения не хватило, поэтому периодически приходилось нырять в переводчик. Английский местами показался вычурным. Перевода на православный пока не существует. После прохождения интересный анонс игры Beyond Shadowgate, которая выйдет в 2016 году (упс, уже 2020, а игры всё ещё нет).

Хочется поиграть в квест с приятным визуальным стилем, как следует поскрипеть мозгами, да ещё и в жанре тёмного фентези? Рекомендую!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972795971', 'num_games_owned': 3898, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1579115936}
review:
What a great update for this classic game! The lore is deep, the graphics are tremendous, the audio sounds great. There are still some lingering puzzles from the NES era that make no sense once you figure them out and seem like they were included just to increase the playtime (because the player would be wandering around clicking on everything hoping they didn't die). All in all, a great remake!

Honestly, the biggest complain I have is that they have a teaser trailer at the end for a sequel that says "Coming in 2016" but there's been no news in quite a while (even in 2020) about that sequel coming to fruition. I want more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030192100', 'num_games_owned': 1993, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1659535677}
review: If you played the original Shadowgate, this is nice trip back in time. However, if you didn't play it, this probably isn't that fun game. You teleport from room to room, loot everything that you possibly can while avoiding traps and instant deaths that lurk everywhere. You have limited time, before all your torches burn out and you have to start again. It's still a good game though, if you like the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198184897393', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 653, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1578357242}
review:
Mixed. The art is great, the game is large with much to explore and interact, and the narrative text never seems to take things too seriously despite the setting; unfortunately, the movement is cumbersome and the enforced move-limit restricts the exploration and interaction.  

Several game modes offer a nice twist on difficulty levels from completely removing the move limitation to adding additional puzzles and obstacles. 

If you have nostalgia for the original (or other classic point-and-click games), or cannot get enough of this genre, I can see it being enjoyed more thoroughly than I have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000895698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1135, 'last_played': 1573193070}
review: I was annoyed at the torch time limit as I, like many of you, enjoy taking my time and exploring everything a game has to offer.  In order to bypass the torch limit, I downloaded a trainer that allowed me to add as many torches as I wanted.  This gave me the opportunity to really learn the different puzzles and how to actually cure the curse time limit without resorting to a guide.  Every time you perform an action, besides any type of Look / Read action, your torch gets consumed a small amount.  This make its difficult, if not impossible, to go through the different iterations of the puzzles to find the answers - short of scumming which I hate having to do.  After playing through Master several times (and dying several times) I realized the torch limitation actually wasn't as bad as I thought, but there's no way I could have done it without the trainer removing the torch limit (or at least retained any level of sanity/enjoyment from the game).  I still highly recommend this game as the 18 hours I spent over the past week were a lot of fun.  The story is interesting and there's a feature called "Hidden Deaths" that allow some unique cutscenes of how you get killed in the dozens of different ways (just make sure to save before hand).

author: {'steamid': '76561198394732752', 'num_games_owned': 182, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1563083623}
review:
Not terrible on its own, but not a great homage to a classic.  The original Shadowgate had you exploring a dark, mysterious castle, and solving puzzles.  You'd snap up every item that you saw, and tried to figure out how they were to be used, sometimes finding that they were not to be used at all.  This was all narrated but a writer with wicked, dry sense of humor, with lines that seem innocuous, but are laden with snark.  Perhaps one of the greatest joys - certainly the greatest unintentional joy - of the original Shadowgate was finding all of the absurd ways to kill your character; almost [i]everything[/i] could kill your character.  Although this - I guess you'd call it a reboot? - has all of that, it manages to fall flat.

The first problem is the large amount of moon logic puzzles.  Yes, the original had them, and walkthroughs are a thing, but it's 2014; I thought we'd all agreed that this was bad design, and that we were going to move on from it.  What makes this especially disappointing is that this game lays a pretty good groundwork, with lots of would-be clever puzzles and spells with some subtle clues, like the original often did.  Make the puzzles challenging, but there should be [b]some[/b] kind of clue about how to solve them, or else, they're just guesswork.  Part of the problem is that there are tons of useless items, strewn about in a "Remember filling your inventory with items you'd never use?  Wasn't that great!?" kind of way; when you have an achievement for picking up 200 different items, it's painfully obvious that you're straining to make some kind of connection to the original.

Another problem is its presentation; the original generally played it straight, with the occasional snarky line or goofy humor thrown in to catch you off guard, and it was balanced very well.  This adds in long cutscenes and lots of backstory, detailing - or more often, glossing over - fantastical worlds that you'll never experience, and the sheer amount just tips the scales a bit too far.  Lore and worldbuilding are wonderful things, but not something that Shadowgate ever needed, unless you're going to actually expand that world within the game, and given that you never leave Castle Shadowgate, it doesn't quite work.  Throwing in a few bits and pieces about the actual castle, the villain's motives, or the nature of the beast was great, but there's this whole big thing about a prophecy, and your lineage, and it all just seems simultaneously unnecessary and too convenient that you'd discover your entire family history by taking on this quest to a castle in the middle of nowhere.  That's not to say that it doesn't occasionally capture the original's great sense of humor - there are still some absolute classics here - but that the lack of balance makes the cutscenes and all of the extra story bits seem to drag on about twice as long as they actually do.  They did even realize that fans love the deaths, and added in a slew of special hidden deaths with their own cutscenes to find, so they had an idea of what to celebrate, but sadly, it just didn't quite come together.

This also has retro features, but they're very hit-or-miss.  There's a whole new look, sound, and even a completely redesigned interface, but if you want the old one, it's right at your fingertips.  The new interface is pretty bad, with some ambiguous icons representing some of the actions.  I know what a foot's going to do, but a hand could be touch, lift, take, press, or any number of other things; a picture is worth a thousand words, but not all of those words are always accurate, and thankfully, the classic interface gives you straight text commands.  The new visuals are not great; they look like a painting that's been left in an unsuitable environment, so all of the colors are smearing and blurring together.  If you're going to go all out, then do that!  If you choose the classic visuals, instead of getting something like the NES version or the old computer versions, it just drastically lowers the image's resolution; it looks like the background of a bad VGA Point-and-Click Adventure, and while an homage, it's not one to anything that Shadowgate's ever been.  With that, the new music is the typical generic orchestral outing, but the old NES music clashes with the new visuals, and with the "classic" visual setting doing nothing more than rendering most objects inscrutable, you don't have a nice pairing for it.

The game isn't without its potential; it just failed to live up to it.  I'd love to see some of the new/expanded elements here used in another game, like maybe a 3D reimagining of Castlequest/Castle Excellent.  Running around in real time, exploring a dark, strange castle, with a variety of vaguely-defined spells and items used to solve various puzzles and progress deeper into its walls sounds like a great idea.  I'd encourage this development team to branch out and make something that is wholly their own.  As for players, I'd recommend the classic MacVenture games, also available here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078996445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 263, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1562115574}
review: I'm glad adventure games over the years have abandoned some of the really annoying things this games does, like random deaths, actions that can result in unwinnable games, and puzzles that rely on brute force trial and error over any kind of logic.  The worst offender in this game is the spells that have no descriptions or any indication of what they do.  So you either cast spells willy nilly on everything in sight until something randomly works or you just use a walkthrough to tell you what to do with every spell  The time limit in this game is also a really terrible mechanic.  At at the low difficulty level I played the game at, it didn't end up being an issue, but I still strongly disliked the feeling that I had to be rushing through everything instead of exploring at my own pace.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013990072', 'num_games_owned': 1513, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1560034426}
review:
I wanted to like this game, but it was surprisingly more tedious and unintuitive than I would've ever expected.


Some minor spoilers ahead, but to name a few examples below in more detail to vent out:
-Spell descriptions are very vague and for the most part I don't know what to use them for and what to use them on, their use is only described as a vague clouded vision of the environment they are to be used in. It would seem like they don't even have a separate utilitarian purpose, like one door-opening spell or one damaging spell, they are all (with the exception of Invoke) just glorified magical keys that can be used only in one particular circumstance and never again. Kind of disappointing that a light spell doesn't actually shed light or blind anything other than one specific enemy it was designed for.
-Despite being equiped with multiple weapons and combat-effective spells, as well as carrying both a shield and a helmet, you'll get instakilled by a goblin unless you decide to punch it in the face. You can defend yourself against multiple instances of dragonfire breathing, but are not competent enough to get a hold of a sword to beat a goblin, at the same time being capable enough to take him down with one punch.
-The Obelisk messages don't actually give you any advice, don't set the goal or explain the world around you, and only serve the purpose of cryptic encouragement to defeat evil.
-How is it logical that a stained glass window shedding light on the floor will point you to it so you can pry open a particular tile to uncover a skull to put into the main entrance outside the area's perimeter to activate the room of mirrors 5km deep into the castle, and how is one supposed to figure it out, and how is one to know afterwards whether the rest of the map doesn't have such particular "puzzles"?
-Overall, there's a ton of backtracking, and transitioning between locations is a real pain after an hour or two.
-The whole catacombs section is just a chore nobody wants to deal with.
